number of helpful: 32 of 35 people (91%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This is, by far, the best thing I have ever seen on the rift. I honestly could not see how they could improve on the 3D experience. The depth and scaling of the scenes really make it pop, and it gives a quite beautiful landscape (think James Cameron Avatar fluorescent night scene type coloring and style). I received almost 0 ill effects from this game (an 8 hours session in half life 2 gives me a pretty bad headache). The game is fun and you can kill time in it pretty quickly without even realizing.  It’s also nice that they allow you to control yourself with both your headset and a keyboard, as they give completely different experiences.However, the game definitely needs some tweaking in a few areas.#1 The random generators can be completely unfair. I once made a perfect run on a track in hard mode, and still lost 30 seconds. Kind of ruins the fun of a game when you are constantly put in unwinnable scenarios.#2 Starting in hard mode, you get a bowling ball type obstacle. This obstacle can also make the game completely unfair. For example, you’re coming up on a 5-protein chain, but have the bowling balls before it. They are not likely to make it through to the red walls. I cannot find a sure way to hit the balls to guarantee at least 1 will get through.#3 Sometimes the vertical climbs can be just a bit too steep, and the red walls come up so quickly, there is literally no time to make a guaranteed dodge, leaving it up to luck.Although, I’m sure these problems can be fixed without having to make any large changes to the codebase, so I expect the authors will be able to get this right some point soon (“A Story About My Uncle” being a great example of early-access developers listening to the fans on gameplay tweaking :-) ). Oh. And achievements are always nice ;-)

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												InCell is an action/racing game with a bit of strategy and educational thrown into the mix.


YouTube™ Video: InCell VR - Gameplay & Review - A Sheepish Look At 

			Views: 1,413		

			Genna plays InCell VR. A Virtual Reality focused game where you enter the human body to fight off a virus. Click here to Subscribe ► http://bit.ly/mrwssub...		

The game is focused on Virtual Reality, but you can play just fine without a set.Your goal is to reach the center of a cell inside a human body, to eliminate a virus.The main gameplay has you constantly driving down a long cyllindrical track, that you can only rotate around to avoid obstacles, get speed boosts or collect protein (money). Within levels, there is a virus chasing behind you, that will kill you if you hit too many obstacles.The level selection actually has a bit of fun strategy to it. You can select which part of the cell you'd like to go to next. Depending on which one you choose, the difficulty of the level will be different, as well as the selection of upgrades you will have at the end. Some will give you more speed, or slow down the virus chasing behind you.The game looks beautiful, and I can only imagine how immersive it can be with a set of VR goggles.Overall, it's a cool game that might interest you, check it out!

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												The Vive support doesn't seem to be working nearly as well as the developer's other game InMind. The "cockpit" that you sit in is smaller and placed at a height that requires you to stand up to see through the front window and use the UI - but the gameplay is designed for seated position. They need to center the cockpit (or is it a helmet?) around your head, or make it room-sized like in InMind. Also, there's no reason why this couldn't use the Vive controllers for steering rather than awkwardly tilting your head. You can see the controllers in-game but they have no effect on anything.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												As a simple racer with a tutorial and three levels this game is not terribly complex, and the fact that it should be relatively short makes it seem like it should be easy to polish off with some practice. Basically you are trying to stay ahead of your enemy (the virus wave) and the clock in the corner will show you how much of a lead time you have on it. If it catches up to you, you're dead and have to restart the level from the beginning. The level is broken into several jumps between organelles with the ultimate destination being the cell nucleus.Unfortunately the game is beset with a bug that hampers progression. While each level increases in difficulty (which is why you'll need some practice), I was never able to make it past level two even though coming close (within the last couple of seconds) several times. I kept thinking this was purely a matter of skill until I began paying closer attention to my choices.As you step though a level you are given a choice of what path forward you want to take and that choice will grant you a bonus depending on what kind of organelle it is -- i.e, a time buff or additional proteins (used as currency in the game). However when I started paying attention I noticed these buffs often were not applied. So for instance I might choose a path that gave me a 10 second time buff, more often than not my clock would be exactly the same going into the next race. Same thing happened for additional currency -- more often than not you wouldn't get it. Yet another bonus will allow you to identify "masked" organelles for the rest of the level so you can better choose your path, but they remain masked.This severely impacts level two because even if you perform each run flawlessly, it's often not enough to stop the virus wave from catching you. Winning is then no longer a matter of skill but instead that PLUS sheer random luck of the game generating easy tracks with optimal placement of speed boosts. And even so the final track of the level (into the nucleus) is always hard (due to having the fewest speed boosts) unless you get a bonus that knocks that final track down to easy. And what do you think the chances are that bonus will be applied? ... yeah, ahem. I have encountered true easy tracks in which you'll lose up to 14 seconds of lead time even if you hit all the speed boosters, so you can imagine what a hard track is like. Rating: 4/10Simple, clean design with good visuals. But not worth banging your head against the desk.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Key provided by developer/publisher. This does not effect my review.Race throghout a cell, aiming to get to the nuculus before a virus does!A mirco-world complemented by streamline visuals. Use a keyboard or VR headset for the best experience!The Good, and the BadPros:-a very good game to pick up for casual gamers-immersive enviroment-fun to race against the clock-fluid gameplay, with or without a VR headset-get edumacated about cells-collect protein along your journey to upgrade certain stats, such as speedCons:-Length: only a couple levels and a tutorial (but who says you cant re-play them)-TMEAR07 (The Most Excellent Assistant Zero-Seven) does not speak english very well, might be intentional, or just a flaw-If you are prone to seizures, warning!SummaryI have found this game to be very fun to play. Even if you hate science, you will find enjoyment in this marvelous game.8.9/10 Curator review for Vantom giveaways. Here is our curator page

												It's fun, but as a fore warning I feel there should be a seizure warning. There are a lot of things happening on screen and you, the player, move at a vary of speeds ranging from mild to a roller coaster. I got somewhat disorientated and I don't want to imagine playing this on VR headset. A few things I want to point out-- the narrator reminds me of the narrator from Stanly Parabole, only female and a robot. She insults you when you mess up and praises you when, from lack of better words, do well. - the control options are nice  +arrow keys +VR headset +and lastly, gamepad-smooth graphics-realistic cell description -interesting background story

												There isn't, as far as I can tell, a real point to this game. I like the idea behind it but I feel the execution was poorly done and developed. The graphics are beautiful and if your playing on a PC (by the way I am happy that a VR game is FINALLY avaliable for those without VR, just wish it could've been a more interesting one) it is extremely user-friendly though I imagine that it is probably better with the actual game-system it was intended for. Nevertheless, all this game is is you swirling around to the finish line to beat the virus. I don't know what I expected from this game, but I definately expected more than this.Overall Rating: 3/10 (would've been 2/10 but +1 extra point for amazing graphics and the idea behind it)

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This game/viciously cruel trick does not make any sense, especially in VR! This is a great example of what a VR experience not be! I for example expected to be inspired by an interesting, scientific, and educational expierience inside of a cell of some kind. What I got was something more like a psychotic, vicious, practical joke on my visual senses. When the game launches the user is imediately and unexpectedly ejected from a peacful existance to a horrible mad-house style, uncontrollable, roller coaster.I can't imagine anyone enjoying this, if you look closely you can tell by the reluctant look on the girls face in the trailer video when she is putting on the HMD she actually looks like she is about to throw up.After playing this game for under five minutes I was literally nauseated/sick all day long, it obviously ruined my day.

												Really fun game.  Some of the most fun sequences are the inter-level scenes where you travel through a cell and see cell structures all around you.  Very cool.The game itself is basically a race along a tube, where head motion strafes you left/right along the tube as you fly forward.  Standing and doing this with the Vive is hard.  Sitting is good, but the head motion control will probably make you a little woozy if you get sick easily.  I didn't get sick, but after almost 10 minutes of playing, I think I would have if I had kept going.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												InCell is a tech demo with weak gameplay that can be a visually pretty look at human cells, whether playing this in VR or not. I cannot recommend this as a game, but can recommend it as a tech demo with motion sickness caution for VR players.Here is why I call this a tech demo: No configuration options except a few hot keys on the Store page, no sound configuration, cannot save progress between stages within a level, when starting a level and panning down the subtitles will clip/hide into the track, very simple collect/boost/slow gameplay, modifiers acquired thus far cannot be viewed, and UI is not always intuitive as to what needs to be clicked to progress or purchase items.

												I bought the overpriced dork-goggles so I could experience new kinds of games, and this one delivered.  This was the first game where nausea was a resource I needed to manage.  I had to navigate a three dimensional track while touching all the green stuff and not touching the red stuff.  But at the same time I had to minimize the motion of my head to avoid puking the orange stuff.It wasn't fun, but it was a novel experience.Time to lie down for a bit.

												Played on vive. It was quite fun, but after 10 minutes I felt queasy and sick. Be VERY carefull with this game if you can get motion sickness at all (this was the first time I got motion sickness and I got my vive 5 weeks ago). Now, I want to throw up.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												The game tries to sell itself as an edutainment title, but there is very little entertainment and much less education involved. Also, the way they have you move is sickening after very short amounts of time, which made me grateful that there was hardly enough content to make this game worth playing for more than 30 minutes. Pass on this one, you won't be missing anything.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												InCell is from the developer of InMind.  A spatial view of a planar obstacle dodge/collect game.The graphics are cute, cartoony blobs of color, and higher levels make it harder to dodge things, adding obstacles that have to be knocked down.A fun way to show friends some of what a vr headset can do, with great effort to prevent motion sickness.The developers are attentive and approachable, a great indie experience!

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Honestly, this is not good VR. It's not a fun game either. It's very pretty to look at but it's completely uninspired and unoriginal. Devs are still working out what makes a good VR game and this is a decent attempt but a failure in my opinion. Spinning around tilting your head while going really fast is going to make you sick too.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												I played this for 10 minutes before it said 'Play again?' Am I right assuming the game is only 10 minutes long? Racing along a 3d tube is pretty uninspiring, unoriginal and very nauseating. I bought this on the back of playing the free demo 'In Mind' which was reasonable, but this is pretty bad. The voice over is terribly cheesy and not necessary too. I expected much more for the price.

content:
Posted: February 11
												Great idea, terrible execution. I don't ever get motion sickness, and there isn't any VR game that I've tried that has gotten me sick. This one though....this one was a close call. Movement is just too fast for VR. Spinning makes it even worse. I REALLY wish this game was playable because it looks pretty fun. The graphics are pretty good too.I honestly have no idea what the developers were thinking. They must not have tried this game with the Vive.
